Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story:
I stood in the crowded polling station, my phone buzzing in my pocket. It was Alex, my boyfriend, texting again. He’d lost his sister just two days ago, and I’d promised to be there for him, to hold his hand through every wave of grief. But today was election day, and I’d already waited forty minutes in line. Suddenly, an official called out, “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line.” My last name was Bennett. The new line was longer, slower, but the official’s voice was firm—this was the rule.

Alex’s messages grew more desperate: “Can you come home soon? I really need you.” I felt torn in two. As a girlfriend, I wanted to drop everything and rush to him, to be the comfort he needed. But as a voter, I was expected to follow the officials’ instructions, to do my civic duty properly. My heart pounded as I shuffled toward the new line, guilt and frustration twisting inside me. I couldn’t be in two places at once, and both roles demanded all of me.
